message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with feeding intolerance and gastric retention, along with lethargy and marked abdominal distension. The digital rectal exam shows stool streaked with blood, indicating possible obstruction. The most likely abdominal radiograph would be option C, which shows significant distension of the bowel loops and possible air-fluid levels, suggestive of bowel obstruction. Options A, B, D, and E do not show significant bowel distension or air-fluid levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with feeding intolerance and gastric retention of formula, as well as a distended abdomen and bloody stool. All of these symptoms suggest necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), a common gastrointestinal emergency that occurs in premature infants. Option C shows the classic radiographic features of NEC, including pneumatosis intestinalis (gas within the bowel wall), portal venous gas, and bowel dilatation. Options A, B, D, and E do not show these characteristic findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has feeding intolerance and gastric retention, which may result in a distended abdomen. The presence of blood in the rectal vault suggests possible necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), which is a common complication in preterm infants. The most likely abdominal radiograph finding in NEC is dilated loops of bowel with air-fluid levels, which is seen in option C.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation suggests that the patient may have necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) which is a condition that affects premature infants. The radiograph that shows dilated loops of bowel with pneumatosis intestinalis (gas within the intestinal wall) in the right lower quadrant is most consistent with NEC. Option C shows the dilated loops of bowel with pneumatosis intestinalis. Option A shows a normal bowel gas pattern, option B shows mild distension, option D shows moderate to marked distension, and option E shows a small bowel obstruction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient in this scenario has feeding intolerance and gastric retention, and is also on nasogastric feeds. These symptoms and the abdominal distension suggest that the most likely cause is necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). Choice C shows the characteristic appearance of pneumatosis intestinalis, which is seen in NEC. Choices A, B and E do not show this feature, and choice D is a normal abdominal X-ray.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with feeding intolerance and gastric retention of formula, along with lethargy and abdominal distension. These symptoms are suggestive of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), a common gastrointestinal emergency in premature infants. The most likely abdominal radiograph findings in NEC are bowel dilation with air-fluid levels, as seen in option C. Options A, B, D and E do not show significant bowel dilation or air-fluid levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has feeding intolerance with gastric retention of formula, and her abdomen is soft and markedly distended, which suggests a possible diagnosis of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). An abdominal radiograph is commonly used to help diagnose NEC, and option (C) shows the characteristic findings of a dilated loop of bowel with air-fluid levels and pneumatosis intestinalis, which is gas within the bowel wall. Options (A), (B), (D), and (E) do not show these characteristic findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has feeding intolerance with gastric retention of formula, and a markedly distended abdomen. The abdominal radiograph that is most likely to be seen in this patient is option C, which shows dilated loops of bowel with fluid levels. This is consistent with a diagnosis of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), a common cause of feeding intolerance and bowel perforation in premature infants. The blood-streaked stool found on digital rectal exam is also consistent with this diagnosis. Options A, B, D, and E do not show dilated loops of bowel with fluid levels, and are less likely to be seen in a patient with NEC.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting signs of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), which is common in premature and low birth weight infants. Among the options, only option C shows signs of bowel dilatation, which is a common finding in NEC. The air-fluid levels and thickened bowel walls are also typical findings in NEC. Options A and E show normal bowel gas patterns. Option B shows an empty stomach and no evidence of bowel dilatation. Option D shows calcifications, which are not typical findings in NEC.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with feeding intolerance and gastric retention of formula, as well as a markedly distended abdomen and blood-streaked stools, which are indicative of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), a common complication in premature infants. The abdominal X-ray in option C shows air in the bowel wall, which is a characteristic finding of NEC. Options A and E do not show any evidence of air in the bowel wall, and options B and D show air only in the lumen of the bowel, which is not specific for NEC.
